title: GBBO's Nadiya Hussain admits upbringing made her 'hate being a woman'
text:
Nadiya delves deep into her past in new book Finding My Voice (Picture: Adam Lawrence/BBC)

The Great British Bake Off winner Nadiya Hussain has revealed that she grew up feeling inferior in the eyes of her family because of her gender, a week after admitting that she was sexually abused as a child.

Ahead of the release of her new book Finding My Voice, the 34-year-old told The i that she struggled to understand her place in the world as a woman growing up, admitting that her father swore at her birth because she wasn’t the boy he had hoped for.

‘I hated being a woman,’ she said.

‘Everything about my existence and that of the women around me sickened me. They were always beneath someone and never on top.’

Despite being raised as inferior to her siblings, Nadiya admitted that she held her own, saying: ‘I learnt that questioning things aggravated my parents. It was the only time I’d get a reaction, the only time they looked me in the eye.’

Now as a parent to three children, the -year-old says she learnt what not to do from her parents.

Nadiya shares three children with her husband Abdal Hussain (Picture: Getty)

‘Of course, there’s a sense of frustration, because I was told constantly, “No, you can’t, you’re a girl,”’ she said. ‘Even now I can hear the frustration.

‘But without that, I wouldn’t be who I am today. I would have raised my kids the way I was raised and nothing would have changed.’

In the memoir’s final chapter, Nadiya discusses being sexually assaulted by a family friend at the age of five, admitting that she didn’t understand what had happened until a secondary school science class, which prompted her to vomit in the lab’s sink.

‘I would love nothing more than to erase some of my memories,’ Nadiya said, adding: ‘But these stories are there to be told.’
